settings.text:
"The biggest risk is not taking any risk," as Mark Zuckerberg, co-founder of Facebook, once said. This speaks to what we strive for every day at Loop by embracing our entrepreneurial spirit to change the world of sound, one step at a time.

In 2022 the team added the idea of "bets" to our corporate culture. This initiative is based on limited time and budget, which allows teams to come together for a project and go above and beyond their regular job responsibilities. These bets can range from boosting sales, social media campaigns, governance (ESG) objectives, or enhancing our employer brand.

The major pro about working in bets-mode is that anybody can participate regardless of position because it's not restricted to a particular department. It is truly an all-hands-on-deck moment!

In this article, we'll dig a little deeper into why we work on bets, some recent bet projects, and talk to one of our founders, Maarten Bodewes.

Why do we work on bets?

Working on bets has been essential for Loop's growth and success. Being able to shift gears when needed in today's rapidly changing business environment and the world is a must. Taking chances to come up with new ideas and innovations is a chance to stay ahead of the game and push Loop’s mission to empower people to live fully at their volume.

As one of Belgium's fastest-growing tech companies, big plans are in the works. By kicking out the status quo and committing to keeping the innovative spirit alive.
Give customers details about the banner image(s) or content on the template.

How did it all start?

One of Loop’s founders, Maarten Bodewes, said, "We want to empower our employees to be entrepreneurs by encouraging them to take risks and try new things; after all, that's what made Loop successful in the first place. Starting the company was a bet!"

Seeing this mindset implemented top-down is a significant reason Loop continues to make waves. Maarten said, "We didn't want to add too much red tape in our bets process, but we wanted to create something that connected back to our company values—initiative and staying curious."

Giving Loop employees the opportunity to take the initiative will give them more impact within the company and provide valuable learning opportunities. Integrating employees thoroughly within initiatives helps everyone feel close and committed while feeling empowered.

Bets help create a dynamic and engaging work environment where employees are interested and motivated when given the freedom to make decisions and take risks.
Give customers details about the banner image(s) or content on the template.

Taking a bet to the streets

A recent bet by a group of Loop employees led by Senior Product Designer Damien Laglera, was to create large QR code panels from 17,000 old carry cases placed in Antwerp strategically. By strategic, we mean location-wise and how noisy the area was.

Hence, this project was perfect for a busy shopping street and the Metropolis cinema complex. Choosing a place where people usually don't realize they're overwhelmed by noise added another layer making it even stronger.

Sparking curiosity was vital; the next step was to see how many people would be drawn to scan the QR code. Once scanned, the code would lead to a webpage with a video about the emotion of sound and how it can reflect and affect emotions.

Pauline De Naeyer, one of the colleagues who worked on this bet, said, "We had no idea how many people would scan the QR code or what their reactions would be, but that was part of the excitement. It was a huge learning experience, and we were happy to see people intrigued with the video."

A highlight from this eco-friendly project was that the company was able reuse the QR code panels to set up in other major cities in the future.

The big pay-off can be seen revenue-wise but also within the company. Damien noted, "Bets push me to come up with new ideas and work in different fields that I'm not used to working in. I can also bring my expertise to other teams."

Taking a bet on the US market

Another bet created was a discount code scheme that Ludovic Diercxsens, Maksim Tokarev, and Jasmin Mirpuri pulled together. The group presented their idea to give military personnel, emergency responders, medical personnel, educators, and students 25% off codes.

Based on the premise that many US businesses provide this kind of discount, the goal was to determine whether these demographics in the US market would be interested.

This bet was a win-win because it allowed us to thank community members and increase sales. The project was successful since information could be extracted to guide future marketing and sales strategies.

Bets in a nutshell

Loop has taken a tip from Silicon Valley and built a corporate culture around bets. Taking the first step is where it all starts, and that crucial first step helps everything else take off. Giving everyone at Loop the space to experiment and even fail is at the core of Loop's values.

The result is a more agile, iterative, and collaborative approach that builds on strengths and bolsters weak spots. This year, we’re aiming high with the hopes of achieving 100 bets to catapult Loop’s mission even further. Bets make Loop a stronger company in the long run, keeping enthusiasm high and expectations geared toward learning—but most importantly better working together.
